newsitem.title: FRANCE: Poll shows French election race at tightest yet.
newsitem.headline: Poll shows French election race at tightest yet.

text.p: An opinion poll on Thursday showed France's parliamentary election race at its tightest yet, with the left-wing opposition snapping at the heels of the ruling centre-right coalition.

The Ipsos survey for the weekly Le Point magazine projected the coalition would get 290 seats in the 577-seat National Assembly in the May 25-June 1 vote, just one seat more than is needed for a majority. The Socialists and their allies would win 264, Communists 22 and the far-right National Front one.
It was the narrowest lead for Prime Minister Alain Juppe's coalition, which now has a huge majority with 464 seats, since President Jacques Chirac called the early election last month.
Two previous Ipsos polls had given the coalition 331 and 292 seats. Polls by other institutes have also found a tightening race, although none has yet given the left a majority of seats.
Of 1,591 voters interviewed on May 6 and 7, 45 percent thought the centre-right had the greatest chance of victory, and just 23 percent reckoned the left was best placed.

But 33 percent said they would prefer opposition Socialist leader Lionel Jospin as prime minister against 32 percent who favoured Juppe. Chirac called the vote saying that France needs a "new elan" to fight record unemployment and enter a single European currency from a position of strength.
